root: ^Let’s not beat around the beret, Ms. Chef Frances.
^You’re hiding something. And I think for your best interest, you should come clean.
^Ms. Chef. I know she does. I saw it.
^No, you didn’t. I see what you’re doing. It’s not working.
^Ms. Chef, I know what I saw.
^I’m coming to you as Ms. Sweet's friend. You’re her friend too, right?
^Loyal enough to cover for someone you find important.
^I’m not covering. Sadie’s innocent. We were together in the kitchen.
^I’m asking why there’s mercury in the building.
^Ms. Chef. I've been able to sniff out mercury since I was a kid.
^Even if there is mercury, it isn’t Sadie’s. And this isn’t any of your business.
^It is if Mr. Bowler, well known Council member, found it.
^Oh, please. That man was stiffer than a pole. He was so clearly on mercury.
^Oh for f- Yes, Tim, I’m confident.
^If you’re so familiar with mercury, you know what it looks like when someone’s on it.
^And since you’re so curious: Sadie’s not dealing.
^It’s me. She’s just holding it for me. Mr. Bowler comes to me for some. There. Happy?
^Every time he was here, so almost every day.
^And how much mercury would you sell him?
^Oh, you know, just a vial or so.
^And why did you sell it? For the money?
^Yeah. He gets his mercury, and he doesn’t shut us down.
^Right. And was he upholding his end of the deal?
^It was going fine and dandy, until he ended up dead in our alley.
^Why would we kill him? So people can call this "The Death Diner?"
^Come on, we have things to hide but we’re not murderers.
^I see. You’ve given me a lot to think about.
^Well don't think too hard, you might hurt yourself.
